subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p:
In this activity, we will continue to explore how a change to a function's formula will alter its graph. In particular, we will see the effect of multiplying the output of a function by a constant number:
k\cdot f(x)
Remember that if you perform some calculation with the output of a function f, you will be performing that calculation with an expression like f(a).
In this first exercise, you will practice writing an expression for the output of a function which has been altered.

li.p: For a function g(x), what does 3\cdot g(5) calculate?
For a function f(x), what does \frac{1}{3}f(x) calculate?
The expression 3\cdot g(5) means 3 times the output when the input is 5.
All of the above. Dividing by 3 and multiplying by \frac{1}{3} are equivalent.

subsection.p: Now, remembering that multiplying outside a function will alter the outputs of the function, interpret the meaning vertical stretches in the next exercise.

statement.p: Suppose the function f(x) represents the price of your favorite whole bean coffee, where x represents how many pounds you buy.
Which expression below means the coffee is only half the regular price?

solution.p:
Since the output of the function f represents the price, then we must multiply outside the function by 0.5. The formula is:
0.5f(x)

subsection.title: Effects on the graph
subsection.p: Now we will see how to apply these concepts to the graph of a function.
First, you will use the graph of a function to complete a table of values by altering the output.

subsection.p: In the previous exercise, you plotted points for the functions y = 2f(x) and \frac{1}{2}f(x). This created graphs which were similar to the original function y = f(x), but whose outputs were either twice as large, or half as large as those of f(x).
This makes sense, because multiplying outside of the function f(x) by a number like 2 or \frac{1}{2} only changes the output values and the output values are the heights of the points.
In the next two exercises, you will continue to explore how multiplying the output of a function by a number will change the graph.
